content:
Diagnosis:		Complex meningioma involving the left sphenoid wing extending to the cavernous sinus, WHO Grade II, Ki-67 index 8%
		Initial diagnosis in June 2017 with progressive changes noted on MRI since October 2023
		Presenting with associated cranial nerve deficits

Treatment:		Surgical resection 2017: subtotal removal due to cavernous sinus involvement
		Adjuvant radiotherapy 54Gy in 30 fractions completed September 2017
		Progression observed on imaging October 2023
		Initiated stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) November 2023
		Trial of bevacizumab for peritumoral edema commenced January 2024
		Symptoms managed with dexamethasone 4mg daily

Current Situation:
	[redacted name] attended today's clinic accompanied by her daughter.
	
	Symptoms include persistent left-sided headache, diplopia, and progressive fatigue.
	Reports difficulty with activities of daily living (ADLs), requiring assistance with dressing and meal preparation.
	
	Functional status has declined significantly, with Karnofsky score reduced to 50.
	Examination reveals left third and sixth cranial nerve palsies with ptosis and limited eye abduction.
	
	MRI from March 2024 shows partial response to SRS with reduction in mass effect but persistent cavernous sinus involvement. No new lesions identified.
	Ongoing peritumoral edema correlates with reported symptoms.
	
	Discussed at neuro-oncology MDT April 2024 with consensus to continue bevacizumab and escalate physiotherapy support.

Plan:
		Continue bevacizumab therapy
		Physiotherapy referral for mobility aids
		MRI planned for July 2024
		Follow-up in neuro-oncology clinic in 4 weeks.
